MC Human OR: The algorithm analyzes the calls and the customers' ratings of them.  It then returns an employee evaluation on the basis of this information.  The manager monitors the performance of the algorithm.
fairness_OR: Artificial intelligence is not so advanced so as to perform flawlessly on this kind of task.  An algorithm that makes some errors might be acceptable if the manager's questions primary concerned the employees as a group (for example, their average performance rating), but here, we're talking about using one score to evaluate one person, and so Chris could get treated unfairly if his is a case in which the algorithm makes an error.
emotion_OR: I think he would be rightfully concerned about the fact that the algorithm is evaluating his performance.  It is unclear how much he can trust the manager to detect any errors in his evaluation.  If the manager were carefully reviewing all the cases, then the automation doesn't even make sense in this case, since there's no lessening in the workload.
trust_OR: As explained above, I think the state of the art is such that most algorithms would still commit a noticeable number of errors on this kind of task.

fairness_OR: The manager has the ability and responsibility to schedule shifts for the appropriate number of employees he or she will need. The only reason I didn't choose Very Fair is because it's always possible that Chris would need to work a different shift because of other obligations or responsibilities.
emotion_OR: It could be that Chris might be somewhat disappointed or frustrated with the schedule because mornings typically tend to be the business time of the day for coffee shops.
trust_OR: With such limited information, it's hard to know the extenuating circumstances for how and why the manager makes his or her employee scheduling decisions. If he or she is a manager, then there's a presumption of competence, which is why I chose Some Trust.
